physDesc.p: There are several corrections of i to ẏ achieved by adding a thin diagonal descender and a dot to a straight minim, suggesting an exemplar with i-spellings, along with some other minor corrections.

handNote.p: Main scribe of pp. 209-224 of this manuscript, including this homily. Horned e, unroofed a, and frequent use of tall s that descends below the line. The hand is much like a hand in Lambeth Palace 489, and also quite similar to two hands in Cleopatra B.xiii: (1) ECHOE handID DP0591 on f. 58r, lines 1-10, and (2) the hand on ff. 56r-57r. A round Anglo-Saxon miniscule, though with a slight tendency to squareness visible in the more geometric shape of a. Ascenders of thorn and other tall letters fork distinctively at the top, with the left part of the fork bearing a thin stroke to the lower left. Frequent tall s. The ascender of eth has a bend to the left in its middle, and its crossbar extends out from the right and curls upward into a club rather than actually crossing the ascender completely. Tongue of e is generally short and square.
